Description.val:
Fire Support System (FSS) provides the United States Marine Corps (USMC) critical operational and logistics capabilities in artillery weapons, fire direction, and targeting systems. FSS provides the systems needed to create a fully networked sensor to shooter kill chain for the USMC Ground Combat Element. This includes the following projects:

Fire Support Mods (FSM): FSM supports a set of Joint Service and Marine Corps unique efforts to address critical operational capabilities in artillery weapons and fire direction control systems and equipment such as Improved Position and Azimuth Determining Systems (IPADS), Joint Terminal Attack Controller Laser Target Designator (JTAC LTD), Global Positioning System Survey Replacement (GPSSR), Marine Artillery Survey Set (MASS), the Modeled Meteorological Information Manager (MMIM), Lethal Miniature Aerial Missile System (LMAMS), and Organic Precision Fires (OPF). OPF is a tiered scalable weapon system that will provide Marines the ability to accurately attack and destroy targets throughout the battlespace.  OPF will increase lethality of the Marine Air-Ground Task Force (MAGTF), reduce collateral damage, and provide an affordable precision strike fire support system.

Common Laser Range Finder (CLRF): The CLRF Integrated Capability (CLRF IC) integrates laser targeting capabilities to provide lightweight man portable targeting systems consistent with Strategy & Vision 2025 and the Commandant's Planning Guidance. The CLRF IC strategy includes replacement of the AN/PEQ-13, the AN/PEQ-17, and the AN/PEQ-25 into a single hand held targeting system, the Next Generation Hand Held Targeting System (NGHTS). This strategy will result in two affordable systems, a target locating system for the Joint fires observer, and a laser designator for the JTAC that will support operational targeting requirements well into the 2030 timeframe as well as provide significant reductions in weight and power requirements.  

Family of Target Acquisition Systems (FTAS): The FTAS provides the MAGTF the capability to locate, identify, and attack enemy indirect fire weapons systems and observe and direct friendly artillery fire. The FTAS consists of the AN/TPQ-46 Firefinder Radar, the AN/TPQ-49 Lightweight Counter Mortar Radar, Acoustic Ground Counter Fire Sensor (GCFS), and the AN/TSQ-267 Target Processing Set. The FTAS is critical in the execution of counterfire and the integration of target acquisition information enabling attack by MAGTF assets. The FTAS also provides artillery firing units the ability to conduct artillery registration and other friendly fire missions. The FTAS encompasses the equipment required to support target acquisition within the target acquisition platoon and is resident in the headquarters battery of each artillery regiment. The program will continue to address system issues that arise due to Diminishing Manufacturing Sources and Material Shortages (DMSMS) items within the FTAS. The USMC assumed the role of Primary Inventory Control Activity (PICA) for the AN/TPQ-49 in FY15 when the Army divested itself from the system.

Target Hand-Off System (THS): The THS addresses a Marine Corps operational requirement for a lightweight, handheld, and digital target acquisition engagement coordination system. The THS is interoperable with all video downlink, Fire Support platforms, and Target Locating Devices designed for the Forward Air Controllers (FACs), Forward Observers (FOs), Fire Support Teams (FSTs), Firepower Control Teams (FCTs), Tactical Air Control Parties (TACPs), and Reconnaissance Teams. The THS provides the ability to integrate video and sensor information to quickly acquire and digitally prosecute targets in day, night, and near-all-weather visibility conditions in order to conduct precise and rapid indirect surface fire support, Naval Surface Fire Support (NSFS), and Close Air Support (CAS).

Advanced Field Artillery Tactical Data Family of Systems (AFATDS FoS): AFATDS FoS consists of three programs: AFATDS, Back Up Computer System (BUCS), and Mobile Tactical Shelter (MTS). The AFATDS automates the fire planning, tactical fire direction, and fire support coordination required to support maneuver from the sea and subsequent operations ashore. AFATDS integrates all supporting arms assets within the MAGTF such as mortars, cannon artillery, rockets and missiles, close air support, and naval surface fire support systems. BUCS is a hand-held computer system designed to provide a backup to the AFATDS in computing ballistic firing solutions, as well as provide survey and meteorological functions in support of artillery. Additionally, BUCS is the primary ballistic firing solution system during Ship To Objective Maneuver (STOM). The MTS is a Lightweight Multi-purpose Shelter (LMS) mounted on a High Mobility Multipurpose Wheeled Vehicle (HMMWV) which protects both the AFATDS and the BUCS from the environment. The MTS enables rapid emplacement and displacement of fire support elements and provides communications on the move.

Lethal Miniature Aerial Missile System (LMAMS): LMAMS is a loitering, precision-guided missile that is man-portable, single-use, and organic at the small unit level.  LMAMS provides precise lethal fires beyond reach of organic direct-fire weapon systems and performs target attack against personnel in the open or in defilade as well as soft-skinned vehicles during offensive, defensive, stability, and civil support operations. LMAMS provides precision lethality, while minimizing collateral damage in complex and cluttered operational areas.

Justification.val:
Beginning in FY19, AFATDS and THS funding has been realigned from BLI 4631, COMMAND POST SYSTEMS to BLI 4733, FIRE SUPPORT SYSTEMS.  Beginning in FY19, FTAS funding has been realigned from BLI 4650, RADAR SYSTEMS to BLI 4733, FIRE SUPPORT SYSTEMS.

FY 2018 Base Appropriation Request: $22.260M

FSM - $4.064M IPADS - Funding procured IPADS replacement systems.  Funding provided support for modernization and upgrades to currently fielded systems. These systems are fielded to both the active ($3.396M) and reserve ($0.668M) components. 

CLRF - $18.196M  Funding continued to procure and field CLRF Integrated Capability (IC), full rate production systems to replace the current capability with enhanced targeting abilities and reduced system weight.   

FY 2019 Base Appropriation Request: $64.926M

FSM - $4.158M  Funding provides support for modernization and upgrades to currently fielded systems.  These systems are fielded to both the active ($3.099M) and reserve ($1.059M) components.  Increase of $0.094M from FY18 to FY19 supports procurement of IPADS replacement systems.  

FTAS - $2.867M  (Active $2.574M/Reserve $.293M) Funding procures ECP Modification Kits and will continue to address DMSMS issues within the FTAS. These kits are fielded to both the active ($2.574M) and reserve ($0.293M) components. Beginning in FY19, FTAS funding has been realigned from BLI 4650, RADAR SYSTEMS to BLI 4733, FIRE SUPPORT SYSTEMS.  Realignment of effort to new BLI in FY 19 and beyond reflects USMC Program Management Office (PMO) reorganization to improve support of USMC OPFOR.
 
AFATDS - $12.521M  Funds continue to procure a modernized, common shelter that will fulfill the requirements of the Mobile Tactical Shelter (MTS) and the Target Processing Set (TPS). Beginning in FY19, AFATDS funding has been realigned from BLI 4631, COMMAND POST SYSTEMS to BLI 4733, FIRE SUPPORT SYSTEMS.  Realignment of effort to new BLI in FY 19 and beyond reflects USMC Program Management Office (PMO) reorganization to improve support of USMC OPFOR.
 
THS - $23.893M   Budget increase of $5.908M for THS (previously BLI 4631) from FY18 to FY19 is due to procurement of VHF (very high frequency) radios required to support digital transmission of targeting and fires data. Funds were also used to procure THS end user devices to support a scheduled hardware refresh.  Beginning in FY19, THS funding has been realigned from BLI 4631, COMMAND POST SYSTEMS to BLI 4733, FIRE SUPPORT SYSTEMS.  Realignment of effort to new BLI in FY 19 and beyond reflects USMC Program Management Office (PMO) reorganization to improve support of USMC OPFOR.
 
CLRF - $15.904M  Funding continues to procure and field CLRF Integrated Capability (IC), full rate production systems to replace the current capability with enhanced targeting abilities and reduced system weight. Engineering Change Proposals (ECPs) will be conducted to increase operational availability and increase system longevity. 

FY 2020 Base Appropriation Request: $35,488

FSM - $4.299M  Funding will continue to provide support for modernization and upgrades to currently fielded systems to include procuring IPADS replacements on a cycle. These systems are fielded to both the active ($3.603M) and reserve ($0.696M) components.  The increase of $0.141M from FY19 to FY20 will support the procurement of additional IPADS replacement systems. 

FTAS - $2.943M (Active $2.645M/Reserve $.298M) Funding will procure ECP Modification Kits and will continue to address diminishing manufacturing sources and material shortages issues within the FTAS. These kits are fielded to both the active ($2.645M) and reserve ($0.298M) components. Increase of $0.076M from FY19 funding is due to an increase in the number of kits produced during FY20.
 
AFATDS - $12.852M  Funds will continue to procure a modernized, common shelter that will fulfill the requirements of the hardware refresh including the Mobile Tactical Shelter (MTS) and the Target Processing Set (TPS). The funding increase from FY19 to FY20 of $2.6M for the MTS shelters is to procure an additional 23 shelters.  Funding decrease from FY19 to FY20 of $2.38M for Hardware Refresh is due to the procurement of new tablet devices which have a lower unit cost than the laptops procured in FY19.  Overall increase in AFATDS from FY19 to FY20 is $0.331M. 
 
THS - $2.439M  Funds will be used to complete refresh of the necessary cabling to support fielding of new VHF radios.  A decrease of $22.300M from FY19 to FY20 is due to the completion of the VHF radio procurement required to support the digital transmission of fires data.  
 
CLRF - $12.955M  Funds will be used to implement ECPs on post Full Rate Production (FRP) CLRF systems to implement capability enhancements and a life cycle extension plan that will extend the service life of the system an additional ten years. The ECP will include a refresh of obsolete components, replace the digital magnetic compass and Input/Output card which will improve usability, and allow digital image export. A decrease of $2.949M from FY19 to FY20 is due to the completion of the procurement of CLRF IC systems. The ECP in FY19 and FY20 accomplishes updates to the digital magnetic compass and short wave infrared duty cycle as well as image export.  It will be implemented into production in FY19 starting at system number 700 and will be retrofitted into the first 700 systems in FY20.

LMAMS - $0.0M  A decrease of $5.583M from FY19 to FY20 is due to the completion of hardware procurement.

OCO: 
FY 2019 Overseas Contingency Operations (OCO) Request: $5.583M
LMAMS - $5.583M Funding procures necessary components to support operations and procures 50 Lethal Miniature Aerial Missile System (LMAMS) All-up-Rounds (AUR).

Name.@footnote: Decrease from FY19 to FY20 is due to the completion of the procurement of CLRF IC systems.

The ECP in FY19 and FY20 accomplishes updates to the digital magnetic compass and short wave infrared duty cycle as well as image export.  It will be implemented into production in FY19 starting at system number 700 and will be retrofitted into the first 700 systems in FY20.
FY20 LCMR Tech Refresh will be an estimated 15 systems.
FY20 MTS procurement will be an estimated quantity of 50 shelters.
FY20 the hardware refresh is to procure new tablet devices (400) for the AFATDS software. FY21 the hardware refresh is to support the AFATDS 7.0 new user interface.
This ancillary hardware components are to support the Mobile Tactical Shelter cables, raceways, and other infrastructure enhancements.
